abstract.text: The NA62 experiment at the CERN SPS aims to measure the branching ratio of the rare decay K + → π + νν with a relative precision of ∼ 10%.
To achieve that goal, it is designed to be exposed to 1.2 × 10 13 K + decays in its fiducial volume.
The unprecedented K + flux will lead to record sensitivities to rare and forbidden decays of K + and π 0 , including those that violate lepton flavour or lepton number conservation.
The expected NA62 performances for lepton flavour conservation and lepton universality tests are discussed.
Relevant on-going or recently completed measurements from the K ± decay data sets collected by earlier kaon experiments at CERN (NA48/2 and NA62-R K ) are also presented.

body_text.text: Introduction

The NA62 experiment at the CERN SPS, which is expected to start data taking in October 2014 and operate until 2017, aims to measure the branching ratio (B) of the very rare flavour changing neutral current decay K + → π + νν with a relative precision of ∼ 10%.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the Standard Model (SM), this decay proceeds via loop and box diagrams and is characterized by maximum CKM suppression.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The SM prediction for the decay rate is B(K + → π + νν) = (7.81 ± 0.80) × 10 −11 [1].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The relatively high precision is in part because the hadronic matrix element can be related to the experimentally well known semileptonic decay rate (K + → π 0 e + ν).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The quoted uncertainty is dominated by the CKM parametric one, which is expected to decrease in the near future.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The smallness of the expected B(K + → π + νν) means that a very large number K + decays are required for 1 On behalf of the NA62 collaboration: Birmingham, Bratislava, Bristol, CERN, Dubna, Fairfax, Ferrara, Florence, Frascati, Glasgow, Liverpool, Louvain-La-Neuve, Mainz, Merced, Moscow, Naples, Padua, Perugia, Pisa, Prague, Protvino, Rome La Sapienza, Rome Tor Vergata, San Luis Potosí, Sofia, Stanford, Turin the measurement.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: According to NA62 design, about 1.2 × 10 13 K + will decay inside its fiducial volume over the data taking.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, since many major K + decay modes (most notably, K + → π + π 0 ) result in π 0 production, NA62 will be exposed to a sample of ∼ 10 12 tagged decays of π 0 produced in vacuum.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The resulting world's largest K + and π 0 decay samples will provide an opportunity to search for a range of novel phenomena.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In particular, NA62 will be well positioned to improve the precision in the searches for K + and π 0 decays violating the conservation of lepton flavour or lepton number, as well as lepton universality tests and searches for heavy neutrinos produced in K + decays.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Lepton flavour violation in kaon decays
Lepton Flavour (LF) conservation is a cornerstone of the Standard Model of particle physics.
body_text.section: Lepton flavour violation in kaon decays

body_text.text: Historically, LF conservation tests have been the standard probe for the non-SM phenomena, and the experimental verifications of this concept have contributed to the formulation of the SM itself.
body_text.section: Lepton flavour violation in kaon decays

body_text.text: However LF conservation is an accidental rather than a fundamental symmetry of the SM.

body_text.section: Mode

body_text.text: The discovery of neutrino oscillations has led to a conclusion that the LF symmetry is approximate rather than exact.
body_text.section: Mode

body_text.text: It also implies that the neutrinos have nonzero masses, which (in addition to constituting a non-SM phenomenon by itself) opens the questions about the possible Majorana nature of the neutrino, as well as the origin of the small (sub-eV) observed neutrino mass scale.
body_text.section: Mode

body_text.text: The LF violating (LFV) processes occur at unobservably small rates in the SM with massive neutrinos, therefore their experimental observation would provide an unambiguous evidence for new physics.
body_text.section: Mode

body_text.text: This underpins the experimental interest in LFV phenomena, including searches for the neutrinoless nuclear double β decays, LFV decays of hadrons (K, B) and leptons (µ, τ), and µ → e conversion.
body_text.section: Mode

body_text.text: In this context, the next-generation high luminosity kaon experiments represent opportunities to push down the limits on LFV phenomena in kaon sector.

body_text.text: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays
The NA62 experimental setup is illustrated schematically in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The main subdetectors are: a differential Cherenkov counter (CEDAR) on the beam line to identify the K + in the beam and provide precise time measurements (sub-100 ps resolution); a silicon pixel beam tracker (Gigatracker); anticounters surrounding the beam tracker to veto catastrophic interactions; a downstream spectrometer composed of four straw chambers operating in vacuum; a RICH detector designed to identify pions, muons and electrons and provide precise time measurements; a scintillator hodoscope (CHOD) providing the trigger signals; a muon veto detector composed of three planes of counters.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The photon veto detectors include 12 large angle annular lead glass calorimeters surrounding the decay and detector volume, the NA48 liquid Krypton (LKr) calorimeter and two small angle calorimeters (IRC, SAC), which collectively provide hermetic coverage for photons from K + decays in the fiducial vacuum decay region.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Part of the experimental infrastructure, as well as the LKr calorimeter, have been inherited from the previous NA48 experiments.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: A more detailed description of the experimental setup and its status is given in Ref.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays
NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The experiment will use an unseparated 75 GeV/c positive beam with a total rate of about 800 MHz, dominated by π + and with a 6% K + component.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The K + decay rate inside the 65 m long fiducial volume located in the vacuum tank will amount to about 5 MHz.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The expected total number of K + decays in the fiducial decay volume over the lifetime of the experiment is 1.2 × 10 13 K + , which is a 50-fold increase in statistics relative to NA48/2.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The NA62 experiment will be equipped by improved (with respect to NA48/2) redundant particle identification systems, including a RICH detector and a high granularity muon detector system, which will be crucial for background rejection.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Moreover, it will achieve improved resolution on kinematic variables with respect to NA48/2.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The momenta of individual beam particles with be measured (which was not the case for NA48/2), and the downstream straw spectrometer operating in vacuum with an increased spectrometer magnet momentum kick (270 MeV/c) and a small total thickness of 1.8%X 0 will provide momentum measurements for the charged secondaries with excellent resolution.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: As a result, mass resolutions will improve by about a factor of two with respect to NA48/2.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: In particular, the K + → π + π + π − invariant mass resolution will improve from 1.7 MeV/c 2 (NA48/2) to better than 1 MeV/c 2 (NA62).
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: This is directly relevant for background suppression in LFV analyses, constraining the signal mass regions.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: For the K + → π − µ + µ + analysis, the higher momentum kick provided by the spectrometer will eliminate the tail towards higher values of the reconstructed π − µ + µ + invariant mass from K + → π + π + π − decays followed by π + → µ + ν decays in the spectrometer, which is a limiting factor in the NA48/2 data (Fig. 1).
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Preliminary trigger strategy studies have been performed for the LFV decays listed in Table 1.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: These decays are characterized by three charged particles in the final state (note that a π 0 is emitted in K + decay together with a charged particle).
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The expected rate of a generic level-0 (L0) three-track trigger is about 0.5 MHz (dominated by K + → π + π + π − decays).
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: It is comparable to the total design L0 rate of 1 MHz.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Therefore the strategy of triggering on all three-track decays (adopted earlier by NA48/2) is not feasible for the high beam rate environment of NA62, and calorimetric L0 trigger conditions have to be considered additionally.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The following L0 trigger primitives have been considered:
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: • Q N : hits in at least N hodoscope quadrants;
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: • LKr N (x): at least N clusters with energy greater than x GeV in the LKr calorimeter;
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: • MUV N : Hits in at least N pads of the fast muon detector (MUV3).
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The following possible charge blind L0 di-lepton trigger conditions can be formed from these primitives: Q 2 × LKr 2 (15) for ee pairs; Q 2 × MUV 2 for µµ pairs; Q 2 ×LKr 1 (15)×MUV 1 for µe pairs.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The total L0 trigger rate provided by these or similar conditions is expected to be below 100 kHz (mainly due to K + → π + π + π − decays and time coincidences of multiple K + decays and/or beam halo muons), and can be accommodated within NA62 data acquisition.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The electron momentum cut-off at 15 GeV/c is essential to suppress the rate generated by the K + → π + π + π − decays, and leads to a partial loss of acceptance for modes with e ± in the final state.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: The above trigger logic will allow the collection of a wide range of rare K + and π 0 decays in addition to the LFV signatures.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Examples include K + → π + + − and π 0 → e + e − decays, as well as a large π 0 → γe + e − sample sensitive to the dark photon production [11].
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Considering the expected number of K + decays in the fiducial volume and the expected acceptances (typically ∼ 10%), the NA62 single event sensitivities are ∼ 10 −12 for K + decays and ∼ 10 −11 for π 0 decays.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Assuming low background levels (which is justified at least for the K + → π − µ + µ + mode, as discussed above), NA62 is well positioned to improve significantly on the current stateof-the-art reported in Table 1.
body_text.section: NA62 prospects for LFV in K + decays

body_text.text: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays
The SM predictions for the leptonic decay rates of pseudoscalar mesons P ± → ± ν (denoted P 2 below) are affected by hadronic and CKM uncertainties.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: However the ratios of decay rates of the same parent meson depend only on kinematic factors and radiative corrections, and can be computed very precisely.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The SM prediction for the ratio R K = B(K e2 )/B(K µ2 ), inclusive of internal bremsstrahlung radiation, is R K = (2.477 ± 0.001) × 10 −5 [12].
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The suppression of the K e2 decay due to angular momentum conservation, as well as the high precision of the SM prediction, make the quantity R K interesting for precision searches for evidence of physics beyond the SM.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: Within extensions of the SM involving two Higgs doublets, R K is sensitive to lepton flavour violating effects induced by loop processes with the charged Higgs boson exchange [13].
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: It has been argued that R K can be enhanced by O(1%) within the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model [14].
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: On the other hand, the potential new physics effects are constrained by other observables such as B 0 → µ + µ − and B + → τ + ν decay rates [15].
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: R K is also sensitive to the neutrino mixing parameters within SM extensions involving a fourth generation of quarks and leptons [16] or sterile neutrinos [17].
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The R K phase of the NA62 experiment (NA62-R K ), which took data in 2007-2008 using beam line and detector of the earlier NA48/2 experiment, has been optimized for a precision R K measurement.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: To minimize the systematic effects, the data were recorded at low beam intensity with a minimum bias trigger; the total number of K ± decays during the data taking amounted to ∼ 10% of that for the NA48/2 experiment.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: A sample of about 1.5 × 10 5 K ± e2 decays with a background of about 10% was collected.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The final result of a measurement based on that data set is R K = (2.488 ± 0.007 stat ± 0.007 syst ) × 10 −5 [18].
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The leading systematic uncertainties come from background subtraction (the background is due K ± decays and the muon halo of the kaon beams).
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The result is consistent with the earlier measurements and with the SM expectation and dominates the current world average, as seen in Fig. 3.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The experimental uncertainty on R K is still an order of magnitude larger than the uncertainty on the SM prediction, which motivates further measurements at improved precision.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: The NA62 experiment can potentially achieve smaller uncertainties: the larger data sample will improve the statistical precision and will allow considering only the kinematic regions with lower back-ground contamination.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: At the same time, improved particle identification, hermetic photon veto and the availability of detectors in the kaon beam line (CEDAR, Gigatracker) will eliminate several background sources.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: A sample of ∼ 10 6 K e2 decays can be collected by NA62 using minimum bias trigger conditions, such as Q 1 defined in Section 4, downscaled by a factor of ∼ 50.
body_text.section: Lepton universality tests in K ± → ± ν decays

body_text.text: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay
The large samples of K ± → ± ν decays collected in 2007-2008 allow precision searches for heavy neutrino mass eigenstates ν H produced in these decays.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: The missing mass spectrum of the K µ2 decay candidates for a subset of the 2007 K µ2 sample used for the measurement of R K = B(K e2 )/B(K µ2 ) [18], corresponding to 1.8 × 10 7 K µ2 events, is shown in Fig. 4.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: The employed "production search" technique is based on the search for statistically significant peaks above background in the region of positive missing mass, corresponding to two-body decays.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: The event signature consists of a single track positively identified as a muon and consistent with originating from a beam kaon decay, with no other activity in the detector.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: Unlike the alternative "decay search" technique looking for specific decay modes of the heavy neutrinos within detector, this method is sensitive to long-lived heavy neutrinos escaping the detector.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: This analysis is sensitive to ν H masses up to m K − m µ = 390 MeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: In practice, the lower boundary of the sensitivity region is determined by the missing mass resolution of the K µ2 peak, and is about 100 MeV/c 2 in this case.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: In the absence of backgrounds, the sensitivity of the analyzed data set to heavy neutrino mixing parameters (the extended PMNS matrix element characterizing the coupling of the heavy-mass eigenstate to the µ flavour eigenstate) would be |U µH | 2 ∼ 10 −7 in the ν H mass range of 100 MeV/c 2 < m H < 390 MeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: However, as indicated by preliminary studies, the backgrounds from beam halo muons as well as hadronic and semileptonic K ± decays limit the sensitivity to the level between |U µH | 2 = 10 −6 and |U µH | 2 = 10 −5 over most of the above mass range.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: This means that the analysis is potentially capable of placing the most stringent limits on |U µH | 2 assuming a neutrino in a high-mass range (300 MeV/c 2 < m H < 390 MeV/c 2 ).
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

body_text.text: As in the R K case, the NA62 experiment can improve the |U µH | 2 limits significantly and is expected to have a wider m H reach, due to much smaller background level and improved mass resolution.
body_text.section: Search for heavy neutrinos in K ± → µ ± ν decay

Summary

Next-generation experiments to measure K + → π + νν will be characterized by intense K + sources and robust background rejection, therefore they will be well positioned to carry out a rich programme to search for very rare or forbidden K + and π 0 decays.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: With ∼ 10 13 K + decays in its fiducial volume over the data taking, the NA62 experiment will have single event sensitivities of the order of 10 −12 (10 −11 ) for a number of K + (π 0 ) decays that violate lepton flavour and/or number conservation, as well as the potential to improve existing limits in a variety of searches for related phenomena.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Related measurements performed with data sets collected during the preceding stages of the kaon experimental programme at CERN serve as a proof of principle, and have already achieved record precisions.
body_text.section: Summary
